Description: Rim and body sherd of South Ionian pottery mug; interior: reserved band at top of rim, glazed (fired reddish) below; exterior: reserved in upper part, black below; inscription on exterior.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The rim and interior slip find parallels with Samian Hera cups. However, unlike Hera cups which have dipinto dedications to the goddess, this cup has a graffito instead. Other similar mugss were found in the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus and thus this shape is not exclusive to Hera (Schlotzhauer 2012 116). For parallels with Hera cups, see British Museum 1888,0601.401, 1888, 0601.402, 1888.0601.403, and 1888, 0601.405. For a similar mug with a graffito inscription, see Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.227.1899. See Johnston 2013, 104-6.
Bibliographic references: Edgar 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis. B: The Inscribed and Painted Pottery (p. 54, no. 22, pl. IV)
Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 697, no. 544)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.897) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
